did.unittitle: Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts collection contains papers of both Alexis de Tocqueville and Gustave de Beaumont, intermixed. The papers include correspondence, personal papers, and autograph manuscripts by Tocqueville (including the autograph manuscript of De La Democratie en Amerique), Beaumont, and their families and associates, as well as autograph copies of Tocqueville and Beaumont documents by contemporary and later copyists, and photoduplicated copies of originals held elsewhere in other public and private collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: For information about Yale's acquisition of the materials which make up the Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts, consult the curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Box 3: Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection is comprised of material formerly classed as: MS Vault Tocqueville. It received preliminary processing and rehousing at several points between 1959 and 1996 during the enlargements and revisions of the original list by George W. Pierson (see below). Further rehousing was carried out in 2014, and box numbers were added to the 1996 version of this finding aid.

The list of Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts (aka Catalogue Y) was originally constructed by George W. Pierson in 1938. Subsequently, it was enlarged and revised in 1959, enlarged again and retyped in 1964-66, with corrections and insertions added in 1970 and 1974. In 1995-96, the list was scanned using OCR software and edited and formatted for online display. At that time, some editorial comments, superceded bibliographies of related publications of possible interest, and recommendations for further studies, since completed, were deleted. To consult a copy of the original paper version of this "Catalogue Y", contact the curator.

As a result of the frequent revisions and additions, by several individuals, inconsistencies in the format of entries and abbreviations will be found. In many instances, provenance of items is noted, as is the identity of copyists. The "present" location (or disappearance, known or assumed) of many originals is noted in the typed copy of White's original catalogue: 1W and 3W (see E.IV.e). For further information on provenance and copyists, see "Table of Abbreviations Used in this Catalogue." For additional information concerning the content or form of this list, consult the curator.

For explanations of additional "catalogues" of Tocqueville manuscripts referenced in the list, see section E.IV.e, "Catalogues and Inventories of Tocqueville Manuscript Collections." For information about additional and related holdings in the Beinecke Library, consult the Access Services staff or the curator.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Sketch
bioghist.p: Alexis de Tocqueville (1805-1859), French politician and author, best known for his Democracy in America (1835, 1840).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts contains papers of both Alexis de Tocqueville and Gustave de Beaumont, intermixed. The papers include holograph manuscripts by Tocqueville (including the manuscript of De La Démocratie en Amérique), Beaumont, their families and associates, as well as holograph copies by contemporary and later copyists, and photo-duplicated copies of originals held elsewhere.
The collection includes correspondence and documents relating to Tocqueville's and Beaumont's visit to the United States, 1831-32, and investigations of the American penitentiary system.
Locations of some originals from which the Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts copies were made are unknown. Some are known or believed to have been destroyed. For further information, contact the curator.

odd.head: Table of Abbreviations Used in this Catalogue
odd.p: Bonnel - "Instituteur" at the Elementary School, Tocqueville, Manche. The copies of the Tocqueville Tocqueville Mss. (i.e., Tocqueville manuscripts at the Tocqueville chateau, see below) were made almost entirely by him: first, for Neal Lambert White (below), then for Prof. John M. S. Allison and the White Collection on deposit in the library, then for GWP and the Yale Library. Until 1930 virtually all his copying was done into bound cahiers or copybooks. Then he used some long, lined legal- size sheets for additional items required by GWP. His hand is very clear and unmistakable. He was a faithful but not very imaginative copyist. He attempted to indicate when the original was not in Alexis de Tocqueville's hand.
Bt. - Gustave de Beaumont (1802-1866).
Bt. la Ch. - The chateau de la Borde, Beaumont la Chartre, Sarthe. The family Gentilhommiere of Beaumont's parents and his own home in later life. (now sold)

Doysie - Abel Doysie, in charge of having copies of French Diplomatic Archives made for the Library of Congress. His secretaries made the copies for White (below) of the Tocqueville American Manuscripts which White found at Redier's office in Paris and set aside temporarily to be copied. These copies were well done by two women: Mme. Desorments and Mademoiselle Anacreon (Mme. Jouhet) on long, lined, legal-size sheets, using the key numbers of White's inventory 3W (1920-1921) (see E.IV.e.).
Fabius - Emmanuel Fabius of Paris, joint owner of many Lafayette manuscripts, and donor of some Tocqueville items to GWP in 1956.
GWP - George Wilson Pierson, who began working on the Yale Tocqueville Archive in 1928 or 1929.
H. - Harvard (Widener) Library.
HJC - Harold Jefferson Coolidge.
HSP - Historical Society of Pennsylvania
Hunt. - Huntington Library, California.
Jardin - Andre Jardin: See E IV.e for information re A.J.; also see E.VI.e.8.
Langavant - Mme. de Langavant of St. Malo, a descendant of Beaumont's brother, Achille.

Larminat - Madeleine (Mme. Michel) de Larminat, daughter of Mme. de Beaumont-Hennocque and great grand-daughter of Gustave de Beaumont. Donor or vendor of most of the Beaumont manuscripts in the Yale Tocqueville Mss., 1953, 1955, 1956, 1964, 1969, 1973.
LC - Library of Congress: Ms. Division.
MHS - Massachusetts Historical Society.
NYHS - New York Historical Society.
Photo - Photograph or photostat.
Pub. Arch. C. - Public Archives of Canada.
Redier - Antoine Redier, author of Comme disait M. de Tocqueville ... (1926), in whose Paris office White found many Tocqueville manuscripts.
Redier Mss. - Tocqueville manuscripts in Redier's Paris office in the years 1920-21.
Robson - Prof. Robson, formerly working on Francis Lieber at the Huntington library (Hunt).
Romanet - Romanet family, branch of Bt. family.
Stoffels - Stoffels family - especially Mlle. Stoffels d'Hautefort.
T. & B. in Am. - Tocqueville and Beaumont in America (1938) by GWP.
Tocqueville - Alexis de Tocqueville (1805-1859).
Tocqueville Tocqueville Mss. - His Mss. at Tocqueville chateau in the years 1929-31.

White - Paul Lambert White (1890-1922). It was White who, as a beginning instructor at Yale, first looked up the Tocqueville and Beaumont families, saw Tocqueville and Beaumont Mss. at Tocqueville, at Redier's Paris office and perhaps also in the hands of the Beaumont family, and made three catalogues (plus some extracts and translations) and started having copies made for Yale by Bonnel and by Doysie's copyists.

did.unittitle: TOCQUEVILLE & BEAUMONT
Tocqueville family background, education, character
a. pamphlet, Episodes de la Terreur , posthumous publication (1867, 1901) by Tocqueville's father, Herve de Tocqueville
b. copy of acte de naissance of Alexis de Tocqueville extracted from Register of first arrondissement, Paris l an XIII de la Republique. (1 p., given GWP by Fabius.)

c. ALS Paris le 24 fevrier 1830 from Comte Herve de Tocqueville, pair de France (father of Alexis de Tocqueville). Asks King for additional pension for a man... a charge that would not long endure "car a 78 ans on a peu d'avenir." Apparently granted. (Given GWP by Fabius) Jardin comments: "L'intervention du Comte Herve pour la mise a la retraite du vieux Juge Lafontaine est interessante, parce qu'a ce moment l'ancien prefet s'efforce de faire avancer dans le tribunal son fils Alexis."

d. see also below:

scopecontent.p: -undated letter presumably written by Gustave de Beaumont on the occasion of his mother's birthday; enclosed in this letter are now two songs presumably of Gustave's composition. The typed poem, I am told, is taken from the Beaumont genealogy, and the column of 13 refers to 13 children--GWP (Larminat to GWP)

Letters and Reports
B.I.a.1. Tocqueville Letters Home, 1831-1832 ("published")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These were in the hand of Gustave de Beaumont and were taken by White from the manuscript of volume 7 of Beaumont's Oeuvres Completes d'A. de Tocqueville. White took only those eighteen which he did not find in original or in copy in the Redier manuscripts, see below B.I.a.2. For an estimate of Beaumont's considerable omissions and alterations, consult White catalogue 1W below, E.IV.e. Beaumont's copies are still in the Tocqueville Tocqueville MSS, T:IV.A.1. Bonnel copied all but the first page of one letter (later corrected) from what White apparently labelled "Paquet 15". As for what may have happened to the originals, see Jardin comments in E.VI.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are the letters which White found with Redier and set aside to be copied by Doysie's copyists as Dossier 3.I (see White catalogue 3W) Jardin states (1963): "Ces copies, faites pour la plupart par Redier, correspondent-elles a des originaux egares? Dans l'etat actuel de mon information, voici ce que je pense:
- les manuscrits des lettres a ses parents et a ses freres n'ont pas et‚ retrouves;
- par contre des lettres a des cousins (Mme de Leusse) ou des amis (Ernest de Chabrol) existent chez leurs heritiers ou les acquereurs de ces bibliotheques."

did.unittitle: B.I.b.1. Lettres de Gustave parti du Havre le 2 avril 1831.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound letterbook of copies. Originally found and copied by GWP at Beaumont-la-Chartre. Presented to GWP by Mme de Larminat and so to Yale in 1955. For list of these letters see below under B.I.b.2. GWP originally supposed that the copybook was the in hand either of Gustave or more probably of his brother Jules. Jardin (1963) identifies the copyist as Gustave himself.
These letters have been copied, annotated and published as:
Gustave de Beaumont: Lettres d'Amerique, Texte etabli et annote par A. Jardin et G. W. Pierson (Publications de la Sorbonne: Serie "Documents"--22, Presses Universitaires de France, 1973)

did.unittitle: B.I.f. Materials on American Penitentiaries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [MS Vault Microfilm 640, reel 1, neg mf]
1. Tocqueville and Beaumont Periodical Reports to the Government on the Progress of their Mission. 1831-32:
-7 juin 1831, Sing Sing, Tocqueville to Felix Le Peletier d'Aunay (draft) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre; For original see B.I.f.2)
-juin 1831, Report to Ministry of Interior on Sing Sing and House of Refuge, with ?s. (draft by Beaumont, 14 pages) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
-juin 1831, Report to Garde des Sceaux on Sing Sing and House of Refuge (Beaumont, 40 plus pages, notes and draft) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
-juin 1831, Report on Blackwell, Bellevue, Bridwell (in Beaumont's hand, never sent) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
-27 juin 1831, Report [?] on House of Refuge, N.Y. (in Beaumont's hand, 30 pages draft) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
-1831, Report on Auburn and Sing Sing to Ministry of Interior. (in Tocqueville's hand, 12 pages draft) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre; For original see B.I.f.2)
-2 7bre 1831, Report to Garde des Sceaux on Penitentiary System and Penal Laws. (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
-6 8bre 1831, Report and questions to Procureur General (in Beaumont's hand, 20 pages draft) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre For original see B.I.f.2)
-10 9bre 1831, Report to Minister of Interior Mole on Boston and Wethersfield (in Beaumont's hand, 17 pages draft) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
-Letters to Ministere des Travaux Publics et du Commerce (in Beaumont's hand, few pages draft) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
-10 Nov 1831, Report to Minister of Interior on Pennsylvania Penitentiary System (in Tocqueville's hand, 20 pages) (GWP note from Beaumont-la-Chartre)
2. Penitentiary Notes and Reports from America in Tocqueville's hand: (from Larminat)
/1/ Projet de lettre ecrite de Philadelphie le 10 9bre 1831 sur le systeme penitentiaire adopte en Pennsylvanie, adressee au Ministre de l'Interieur. 20 folio pages.
/2/ Rapport sur "La Societe de discipline des prisons". 114 pages folio et 4to.
/3/ Notes diverses sur les prisons des Etats-Unis, les ecoles de prisonniers, les statistiques, les moyennes des detenus dans les differents Etats. 90 pages folio et 4to.
/4/ Rapport sur la prison de Sing-Sing, sous forme de projet de lettre, envoyee d'Auburn le 14 juillet 1831, adressee au Ministre de l'Interieur. 12 folio pages.
/5/ Notes sur les penitenciers de Richemont, Baltimore, etc. Nombreuses notes statistiques. 27 folio pages.
/6/ Rapport sur l'Etat de Maryland. 12 folio pages.
/7/ Rapport sur l'Etat de Connecticut. 14 folio pages.
/8/ Rapport sur l'Etat de Massachusetts. 10 folio pages.
/9/ Rapport sur Philadelphie. 17 pages folio et 4to. including 2 pages later notes.
/10/ Rapport sur l'Etat de New-York. 24 pages folio et 4to.
/11/ Rapport sur l'Etat de Pennsylvanie. 21 pages folio et 4to.
/12/ Tableaux des individus entres dans les prisons de Newgate et de Sing-Sing, classes par nature de delits. 19 pages 4to.
/13/ Projet de lettre a son cousin Felix Le Peletier d'Aunay, sur le systeme penitentiaire, ecrit a Sing-Sing, le 7 juin, 1831. 12 pages 4to.
/14/ Extrait du rapport de la "Society and house of refuge for the reformation of Juvenil delinquants." 3 folio pages.
/15/ Notes sur les prisons des Etats-Unis, classees par ordre alphabetique. 13 pages 4to.

/16/ Carnet de notes sur les prisonniers, en partie inedit, de 32 pages, dont 17 de la main de Gustave de Beaumont, 12mo, contenant des interviews de tres nombreux prisonniers americains. Some of Tocqueville's written over in ink.
3. Notes and Manuscript in Tocqueville's hand for Du Systeme Penitentiaire aux Etats-Unis . (Originals from Larminat)
/1/ Notes sur les chatiments corporels. 5 pages 4to.
/2/ Notes sur les colonies agricoles. 17 pages 4to.
/3/ Le pauperisme en Amerique. 4 pages 4to.
/4/ Emprisonnement pour dettes. 2 pages 4to.
/5/ Notes sur les prisons. 10 pages in. 4 dont 5 pages de la main de Gustave de Beaumont.
/6/ Notes statistiques sur les differents Etats. 39 pages 4to.
/7/ Statistiques sur les femmes et sur les negres en prison, etc. 29 pages in.
/8/ Notes comparatives sur les differents Etats. 18 pages 4to.
/9/ Tableau des criminels par rapport a la population. 5 pages 4to.
/10/ Tableau statistique. 20 pages 4to.
/11/ Notes diverses c. 20 pages including opinion of Mr. Smith.
4. Notes and Manuscripts for second edition [?] of Du systeme penitentiaire [?] (Originals from Larminat)
/1/ Draft of letter by Gustave de Beaumont submitting report to Secretary of State for Public Works and Commerce.
-Gustave de Beaumont: "Historique du Systeme Penitentiaire"
-Gustave de Beaumont: Maisons de refuge.
-Gustave de Beaumont: Discipline (Auburn)
5. Undated Fragments. (Originals from Larminat)
-Gustave de Beaumont: 7 aout Prison de la Roquette
-Tocqueville note on penitentiary of Geneva [?].
-Scraps and notes in Tocqueville's hand: prison statistics, etc. (Larminat)
6. Miscellaneous Beaumont Prison Materials. (Originals from Larminat)
-Projet de Prison Centrale and law of 9 avril 1819 with La Rochefoucauld quote.

-manuscript bibliographic lists for central penitentiary systems of New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Connecticut; for hospitals, etc.; for manuscript docts en penit. system and judiciary (including manuscripts from McIlvaine, Welles, Judge McLean)
-bibliography in six packages as turned over to the French Government by Beaumont and Tocqueville, including general works, houses of refuge, Newgate, Auburn, Maryland, commerce and public works.
-notes and translation of parts of Boston Prison Discipline. See report 2 jan. 26.
-unfinished manuscript by Beaumont - some kind of prison report, 55 pages both sides with first seven missing.
-draft report by Beaumont to Garde des Sceaux on Maisons de Refuge, 20 pages
-draft report to Ministry of Interior 10 Nov. 1831 on prisons of Boston and Wethersfield.
-report (not sent) on Blackwell's I., Bridwell, Bellevue.
-draft June 1831 on Sing Sing and N.Y. House of Refuge, to Ministry of Interior.
-Westchester Herald 26 April 1831 marked: Antidote to Boston Prison Discipline Society Report.
-manuscript notes from Robt. Wiltse and of Recorder Riker's views 22 May 1831.
-notes from annual prison reports.
-plan and manuscript ground plan of Sing Sing prison and grounds.
-draft of letter to Pres. [?] Genl. 6 8bre 1831.
-translation of brochure on rules and regulations.
-miscellaneous notes on Philadelphia prisons and House of Refuge.
-notes and questions on N.Y. House of Refuge, with some answers of Mr. Hart.
-notes on Auburn, Boston, Wethersfield.
-draft of letter to be sent to State Attorneys General.
-note on Liverpool statistics.
-pencil note on Bellevue, Bridwell.
-requisitions and work reports of N.C. Hart.

-Drafts of questions on penal codes and penitentiary systems, including several versions corrected in pencil in other hands or expanded to cover particular areas such as New Hampshire. One such document served as a model of a letter to be sent to the American prison wardens whom Tocqueville and Beaumont were not able to visit. (Larminat)
-Copy of a letter that we intend to direct to the General Attorneys of some States (a modification of previous drafts with inserted corrections). (Larminat)
-Some questions on crime in Massachusetts (in pencil) (Larminat)
-Lithograph of Eastern State Penitentiary at Cherry Hill (Larminat)
-Beaumont note on emprisonment absolu (Larminat)
-Empris[onnement]t solitaire Auburn (in Beaumont's hand) (Larminat)
-Plan of a new prison invented by Col. William Powers... Auburn. (Larminat)
-Note on costs in smith and machine shop (with Tocqueville note giving source) (Larminat)
-Longhand copy of article in Times of London of 31 Dec. 1831, reporting on progress of their prison mission. (Larminat)

-Two questionnaires on American prisons and prison reforms, each apparently a fair copy by some American copyist, presumably in Philadelphia. Both in English. The one-page questionnaire has no date or signatures. The four-page questionnaire is signed individually by Gustave de Beaumont and Alexis de Tocqueville, and is dated in Beaumont's hand: Philadelphia, the 19th November 1831. There is also a postscript in Beaumont's hand requesting that the answers be sent in care of the French Minister Serurier in Washington. (Larminat to GWP)

did.unittitle: American Trip Diaries & Notes
a. Tocqueville Travel Diaries: (Copies by Bonnel from Tocqueville Tocqueville MSS)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: -Cahiers Portatifs: 1-2-3-4-5: Itinerary and some conversations. (Cahiers 1-2-3 copied from Tocqueville Tocqueville MSS, Paquet 18; Cahiers 4-5 copied separately in 1930)

did.unittitle: C.I.b. Tocqueville Correspondence with his wife, Mary Mottley: 183?-1859.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tocqueville's letters to his wife have presented a problem. In 1930 [?] GWP saw some extracts or fragmentary copies from a few early letters, purportedly in MM's hand (see beginning and end of list below), and was led to believe that all the originals had been destroyed. Many years later GWP and the Yale Library acquired from Mme de Larminat the originals of 29 other letters, often undated, and numbered (out of their probable order) in red ink. These have now been put into the sequence suggested by Hugh Brogan. See Brogan's informative and suggestive discussion of them in the C.I.b. folder. (GWP 1964)
-18 mai 1832, "A! le triste temps...", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (GWP extract from copy in Tocqueville Tocqueville MSS)
-3 juin 1832, "... Je suis triste et inquiet, Marie." Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (GWP extract from copy in Tocqueville Tocqueville MSS)
-20 juillet 1833, Naqueville, Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (GWP extract from copy at Tocqueville?)

-19 xbre 1837, Paris, "J'ai ete tout a fait peine hier..." (red ink #"22") (Original from Larminat)

-vendredi [1 August?] 1844, "A peine etais-tu hier dans la voiture...", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"26") (Original from Larminat)
-ce jeudi matin, [August 7] 1844 [Paris?], "Je t'aime de tout mon coeur ...", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"30") (Original from Larminat)

-15 aout 1846, Cherbourg samedi, "je ne veux pas aller plus loin...", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"21") (Original from Larminat)
-[Paris?] 7 [August?] 1846, "Quoique je t'aie ecrit hier... j'aime a le faire de nouveau ", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"29") (Original from Larminat)
-samedi matin, [August] 1846 [Paris?] "je n'ai point parle hier...", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"20") (Original from Larminat)
-20 aout 1848, St. Lo, ce vendredi, "Je suis arrive hier 8 au soir ici", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"14") (Original from Larminat)
-[St. Lo?] ce jeudi soir, 1848 [or 1849?], "je viens, amie cherie, de trouver", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"14") (Original from Larminat)
-ce jeudi soir [St. Lo?] 1851, "chere amie, je t'ecris a la hate..." Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"l8") (Original from Larminat)

-[1851?] NacquevilIe, ce dimanche matin, "J'esperais avoir une lettre de toi hier...", Tocqueville to Mary Mottley (red ink #"10") (Original from Larminat)

-Three undated documents, in letter-note form, quoting from Tocqueville letters. Copyist was probably his wife, Mary Mottley.
1. "Pensees detachees d'Alexis. Ceci n'est point une point une exageration... a le risquer. " (Copy from Larminat)
"Je n'ai jamais pu partager... atteintes du tems" (A love letter, probably rather early, addressed to "vous". Admits he thought he had been in love 12 years earlier.)

2. 2 Pages: "Dans la citation que tu me fais de ses lettres... males ou femelles, je n'en exempte aucun." (A letter expressing his scorn for the bourgeois and the priests who fall over themselves for the new dictator.) (Copy from Larminat)
3. 2 1/2 pages, 2 quotations. "Vous dites peut-etre avec raison que j'attache trop d'importance, quant a la foi, aux accidents de la conduite du clerge... derriere eux."
"le seizieme siecle... harmonie d'ensemble."
-empty sleeves, the first in Redier's hand, the second in Clementine's hand, purporting to contain extracts of the letters of Tocqueville to Clementine (Larminat to GWP)
-deaths of Alexis and Mary Mottley
-Cannes, 4 mars (postmarked 5 mars 1859), letter of Mary Mottley to Clementine de Beaumont asking forgiveness for insisting that Gustave come to stay with them at Cannes (Larminat to GWP)

-undated letter and undated note (both evidently from the end of 1864) from Mary de Tocqueville to Gustave de Beaumont, asking him to come bury her and take care of her affairs as she will have died (Larminat to GWP)

-23 Xbre 1864, letter from H. Thion from Valognes, announcing the death of Mary de Tocqueville to Clementine de Beaumont, and enclosing a lock of hair (on verso, "recit de la mort de Mme de Tocqueville, le 22 dec. 1864" in Clementine's hand) (Larminat to GWP)
-two cards: "Priez pour l'ame de Marie Mottley" (Larminat to GWP)

did.unittitle: Manuscript drafts, etc. for De La Democratie

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These drafts would be of considerable value in an analysis of Tocqueville's methods of composition, and they also contain materials that finally were not included in Tocqueville's book. GWP saw all these (except l.) at Tocqueville about 1930 or 1931 and had Bonnel copy them. In 1954, Yale bought "No. 9" at the same time as it acquired the working manuscript of De la democratie en Amerique , (see below C. VI) but the other Paquets are no longer apparently in the Tocqueville Archives. Whether any of them got included inadvertently in Paquet "9" remains to be ascertained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In May 1954 Yale bought from Comte Jean de Tocqueville the manuscripts of De la Democratie en Amerique and all Tocqueville's notes for that work. It turned out that only "Paquet No. 9" (C.V.g.) of the notes could be found, all the rest of the ten "paquets" having disappeared since Bonnel copied them for Yale about 1930-31 (see rest of C.V.). The manuscript of Democratie turned out to be the working manuscript in Tocqueville's hand (C.VI.a.), which differs slightly from the printed text. An intermediate fair copy, in another hand but probably with Tocqueville corrections, was noted by GWP at Tocqueville in 1930-31, but has apparently since disappeared (C.VI.b.).
a. Original working manuscript of De la Democratie en Amerique (4 boxes)

b. Fair copy - possibly still in Tocqueville Tocqueville MSS. Noted by GWP in 1930-31. (The fair copy of at least one chapter is included in the original working manuscript. See C.VI.a. Box 4, for the chapter entitled "Suite des chapitres precedents")
A microfilm of C.V.g and C.VI.a was made in 1967.
The film is kept in the Beinecke Library.

Tocqueville & Beaumont Lives
"Du Systeme Penitentiaire" (1833) (Cf. above B.I.f.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mainly a package covered and titled by GWP in 1930, "Notes, documents, manuscrits sur le Systeme Penitentiaire aux Etats-Unis." This package filling almost a box turns out to be a miscellany of scraps in Beaumont's hand beginning with some notes for a second edition on:
-intemperance, French prisons, pay rates, etc.
-130 pages of manuscript draft (on some phase of report ?)

-series of notes on variety of prison aspects: pardons, workshops, maintenance, costs of American prisons, grouped under the name of each prison with calculations and notes on the past history (and an occasional note that Tocqueville should do this and translate that.)
-projet de Prison Centrale
-Beaumont's introduction for the second edition... 16 pages.
-Review of Systeme Penitentiaire in "Renovateur", 28 July 1834.
-Additions, observations, supplementary notes of German translator, Julius (in Louis de Kergorlay's hand).
-corrections by page and line, (in some other hand).
-Tocqueville notes on Maison de Corrections: Hotel Bazancourt.
-letter thanking Beaumont and Tocqueville for the copy of their book by T.B.N. Sarguin [?] on behalf of "le Conseiller" (Larminat)
-longhand copy of a long article on Tocqueville and Beaumont's prison report, evidently favorable. (Larminat)

Note: Mme de Larminat said that many of Beaumont's notes and papers were destroyed by rats and water leakage, in the Chateau de la Borde, and that the debris was thrown out at a given moment in house cleaning a number of years ago. Those were all that could be found in the 1950's, when the papers came to Yale.
[MS Vault Microfilm 640, reel 1 and 2 neg. mf.]

did.unittitle: Marie, ou l'Esclavage aux Etats-Unis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Aside from one printed review of Beaumont's book, these documents comprise many miscellaneous notes and parts of a series of early drafts (from Mme de Larminat). The following analysis and comments may be of some guidance.
Text (pub. in 2 vols.) Yale MSS.
Tome Premier
Avant Propos

I. Prologue (1 page only)
II. Les Femmes
III. Ludovic, ou le Depart de Europe
IV. Interieure d'une famille americaine
V. Marie
VI. L'Almshouse de Baltimore
VII. Le Mystere

(Much of these chapters represented in manuscript chapters "IV. L'Almshouse and V."Scene d'Amour." The manuscript opening and mise-en-scene is that of Marie, but there are materials also for Le Mystere, and apparently the great bulk of the Almshouse chapter. It is interesting to note that the names of the chief characters were originally different; Melina, Alphonse, Don Carlos. There seem to be also some extra pages of notes.)
VIII. La Revelation

This chapter was originally entitled V. ou VI.
Le recit ou l'esclavage. Again the names are different.

IX. L'Epreuve, 1.
X. Suite de l'Epreuve, 2.
XI. Suite de l'Epreuve, 3. Episode d'Oneida.
XII. Suite de l'Epreuve, Litterature et Beaux-Arts
Appendice.
Note sur la condition sociale et politique des Negres esclaves...
Tableaux Comparatifs...
Notes:

sur les femmes...
sur les sentiments mutuels...
sur les banqueroutes
sur le Duel en Ameriques
sur la Sociabilite des Americains
sur l'Egalite
Tome Second
XIII. L'Emeute
Beginning same; no other chapter mixed in; notes to page 15 rather complete. Perhaps two versions of this chapter present?
XIV. Le Depart de l'Amerique civilisee.
Entitled "XIII. Depart pour le Desert." Again perhaps two versions of text. Mass of notes, some evidently for preceding chapter.
XV. La Foret Vierge et le Desert.
Labelled chs. XIV. and XV. Apparently rather incomplete. Some pages and notes in second bundle.
XVI. Le Drame
Title "Drame." Two versions correspond. 50 pages plus earlier notes.
XVII. Epilogue
Some pages missing; much crossed out in manuscript; passages do not correspond. Includes note to Tocqueville saying he was trying to avoid duplicating Chateaubriand.
Appendice

Note sur le mouvement religieux aux Etats-Unis.
Note sur l'etat ancien et la condition presente des tribus indiennes...
Notes sur les evenements arrives a New-York, les 9, 10 et 11 juillet 1834.
Miscellaneous page notes.
There seem to be at least preliminary drafts, newspaper extracts, and notes of some sort for most if not all of these Appendix materials.
Comments on these materials for Beaumont's Marie.

Two rather bulky bundles, perhaps five or six inches thick, containing manuscript drafts of the text and notes for the writing of the first fictional tragedy to be published on the race issue or the melancholy fate of the blacks in the United States.

These papers represent an early stage in the composition of Beaumont's pioneer book, and they represent that incompletely. If any more were found at Beaumont-la-Chartre or in the possession of Madame de Larminat we would by the terms of our understanding become the owners. As it is, these two bundles contain only the lesser parts of what the family must once have owned. So far as we can tell, the rest has been destroyed.

From the first volume, materials on 4 out of the 12 chapters. From the second volume, much fuller materials on all 5 chapters, plus extensive materials on the notes. It may be that the second package also covers some of the appendix notes of the first volume. The manuscript is in crude shape and considerable confusion. Without further study it is difficult to give an exact analysis. It does appear, however, that we have materials relating to somewhat more than half of the original 726 pages of printed text.

Imperfect as is this manuscript it offers a number of interesting clues and suggestions. We learn from it, for example, that in the preliminary stages Beaumont's characters had different names, and that Beaumont deliberately tried to avoid echoing the great Romantic, Chateaubriand. These drafts also throw light on Beaumont's method of composition and on a different order of chapters from his first draft.
I am increasingly impressed with the significance of Beaumont's Marie .

Gustave de Beaumont was overshadowed by his diminutive but more brilliant friend, Alexis de Tocqueville, when he undertook himself to write a commentary on the United States, dealing with the social and racial character of the American people. For his own fame he had the further misfortune to cast his materials in novel form. Even so, his work attracted considerable attention in France. But it was never translated into English.

We now find that Marie was apparently the very first novel ever to be published in the United States making the tragedy of the colored races, especially of the Mulatto or free Negros, its central theme. The first comparable book in this country was an anonymous work, later claimed by the historian Hildreth, which was got out in 1836, the year after Marie . The classic, Uncle Tom's Cabin, by Harriet Beecher Stowe, did not appear until 1852. We have here therefore an Uncle Tom's Cabin written 17 years too soon and never until 1959 translated into English. (Cf. Introduction by Alvis Tinnin in that translation, Stanford University Press)
From a number of other points of view this book has genuine significance. Among the questions that it raises are the following:

1. Where did Beaumont get his idea and his attitude? I think it will be very interesting to explore the background of Beaumont's thinking in Chateaubriand, in the uprising of Toussaint L'Ouverture, and in such earlier Romantic classics as Paul et Virginie . It will be possible, I think, to show that the tragic black or mulatto first appears as an incidental character, on the margins of the story as the servant of the master, etc., and then from the wings slowly comes to center stage.

2. Where did Beaumont get the actual material for his own story? Here we already have in the Tocqueville collection and in my book extensive materials to explain the factual content, and the moving incidents which helped to give body and emotional content to the novel. Here are the story of the crazed Negro and the almshouse, the French exile of Lake Oneida, the Journey into the wilderness of Michigan, etc., etc., all from Beaumont's personal experience in America. (see Chapter 38 of my book.) As a further aid we have in the Tocqueville collection a microfilm of an M.A. Thesis written on Beaumont's Marie some years ago by a Kentucky student, who made us this present in return for the privilege of using the Tocqueville materials. (see D.V.)

3. The relation of Marie to French politics and Beaumont's career. In the 1830's a number of French writers appear to have attacked the slavery problem in less literary ways, and Beaumont later went on to become the champion of emancipation for the North Africans in the French colonies. In the Chamber, railroads and colonies were his specialties. In French life the emancipation question had a distinct place.

A number of the above suggestions were explored by Alvis L. Tinnin in his Ph.D. Thesis for the French Department (which see). See also Tinnin's Introduction to the Barbara Chapman translation of Marie (Stanford University Press) and Fabian's Review (D.IV.o.).

did.unittitle: L'Irlande

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nine bundles and some miscellany. Seen by GWP at Beaumont-la-Chartre in 1930. Acquired in 1956 from Mme de Larminat. These consist of a great miscellaneous mixture of notes, statistics, ideas, topics, and quotes from other authorities. They contain at the same time drafts (ca. 1839) of a considerable section of Beaumont's book L'Irlande, and at least some materials, I should judge, on a greater part of the chapters. The titles or labels put on each package by GWP in 1930 correspond only roughly to the contents, but, in comparison with the printed book, one might be able to set these papers in order and shed some light on the composition of the work. There are materials also on the revision of the sixth printed translation of the book, edited by W.C. Taylor, 2 volumes, 1839, with marginal notes; and a copy of the first edition in 2 volumes with Gustave de Beaumont's autograph and a few pencilled marginalia, also acquired from Mme de Larminat. GWP owns a French edition or two.
Description of contents, prepared by Eduardo Nolla, August 1985:
Box 1
Manuscript of vol. I of L'Irlande.
Box 2

Beaumont's copy of 1839 English edition, with marginalia.
Manuscript of vol II of L'Irlande.
Box 3

Manuscript of vol II of L'Irlande.
Book catalogues and lists of books.
Outline of L'Irlande.
Program of 11 June 1840 session of the Academie Francaise. Prize of 6,000
Francs for L'Irlande.
Lecture pour l'Academie.
Notes for Vol. II.
Boxes 4-6
Notes and drafts for vol. I of L'Irlande.
Also:

-Marginalia, probably by Tocqueville, in several chapters.
-Note by Drummond to Gustave de Beaumont
-Visiting card of Comtesse de Meulan.
-Note by Penhonet [?].
-5 issues of the Dublin Evening Post (January 12, 1837; February 7, 1837; February 9, 1837; March 25, 1837). -1 issue of the Journal des Debats (22 mai 1825).
Boxes 6-8
Notes and drafts for vol. I of L'Irlande.
Also:

-Rodd to Gustave de Beaumont, London, July 3, 1837.
-George C. Lewis to Gustave de Beaumont, 17 Henrietta Street, Cavendish
Sq., July 20, 1835. -George C. Lewis to Gustave de Beaumont, 17 Henrietta Street, Cavendish
Sq., no date. -Notes by George C. Lewis.
-Visiting cards of William Wood and George Combe (of 23 Charlotte Square).
-A Bill entitled: An Act for the regulation of the Proceedings and Practice in certain Offices, and the Salaries and Fees of certain Officers of the High Court of Chancery in England.
-Charles Renouard, "Memoire sur la statistique de la justice civile en France." (Extrait de la Revue de Legislation et de Jurisprudence, tome I, 5e livraison). Paris: Au Bureau de Redaction, Feevrier 1835)
-2 issues of the Journal des Debats (2 septembre 1835; 17 mai 1838).
-1 issue of The Freeman's Journal (August 18, 1838).
-4 issues of the Dublin Evening Post (January 17, 1837 (clipping); November 23, 1837; February 25, 1837; October 2, 1838).
-1 issue of The Morning Chronicle (June 20, 1837).
-1 issue of The Warder (July 29, 1837).
-1 issue of the National de 1834 (20 fevrier 1836).
-1 issue of Courrier de la Sarthe (16 fevrier 1838).
Boxes 8-9
Notes and drafts for vol. II of L'Irlande
Also:

-Extract from a speech of Mr. Wyse, July 19, 1832 in hand other than Gustave de Beaumont's.
-Voting papers.
-10 issues of the Dublin Evening Post (February 11, 1837; February 13, 1837; September 19, 1837; December 9, 1837; December 30, 1837; March 3, 1838; March 6, 1838; November 1, 1838; April 3, 1838; August 7, 1838)
-2 issues of the Journal des Debats (18 octobre 1835; 5 mars 1838).
-A bill entitled: An Act to authorize the Commissioners of his Majesty's treasury to purchase the Duties of Package, Scavage, Balliage, and Porterage belonging to the Corporation of London.]
Boxes 10-11
Notes and drafts for vol. II of L'lrlande.
Also:

-"Exposition de la situation malheureux de l'Irlande", notes by _______.
-Visiting cards of the Comte et Comtesse Louis de Beaumont and General Cass (Envoye extraordinaire et Ministre Plenipotentiaire des Etats-Unis d'Amerique pres de S.M. le Roi de France).
-Two pages from Marie.
-Note by Capt. Roberts.
-Draft of letter to Salvandy, Armagh, 20 juillet 1837.
-Note by Mr. Finlay.
-James Armstrong, A Sermon vindicating the principles of unitarian christianity... Sunday, June 17th 1838 (With inscription).
-George Grote, Vote by Ballot. Speech of George Grote, Esq. in the House of Commons, on the 8th of March, 1837.
-Francis Burdett, Resolutions on Parliamentary Reform, moved by Sir Francis Burdett, in the House of Commons, on Tuesday, the 2d of June, 1818.

-David O'Croly, An Address to the Lower Orders of the Roman Catholics of Ireland. Cork: John Bolster, 1835.
-Discours de M. O'Connell (Extraits du National de 1834 des 24 et 25 septembre 1835).
-Discours de M. O'Connell (Extrait du National de 1834 du 19 septembre 1835).
-Mr. Roebuck's Democratic Speech.
-Dr. Murray's Letter to the Rt. Hon. Lord Melbourne.... Dublin, 1835.
-Isaac Tomkins, Thought upon the Aristocracy of England. Sixth edition. London: Henry Hooper, 1835.
-Peter Jenkins, A Letter to Isaac Tomkins, author of Thought upon the Aristocracy. London: Henry Hooper, 1835.
-Timothy Winterbottom, A Letter to Isaac Tomkins and Peter Jenkins on Primogeniture. Second edition. London: Williams Pickering, 1835.
-Peter Jenkins and Isaac Tomkins, A Sketch of the Aristocracy of England, in the year 1835, by Isaac Tomkins and a Letter to that Gentleman, on the same subject, by Mr. Peter Jenkins. London: Effingham Wilson, 1835.
-8 issues of the Dublin Evening Post (December 10, 1836; December 17, 1836; January 14, 1837 (with supplement); January 21, 1837; April 6, 1837; November 18, 1837; December 19, 1837).

-1 issue of The Protestant Penny Magazine, Dublin (August 1835, no. XIV, vol. II).
-1 issue of The Irish Protestant (no. XVI, vol. I, 1835).
-2 issues of La Gazette de France (23 mai 1834; 24 mai 1834).
-1 issue of the Journal de Paris (25 janvier 1836).
-3 issues of the Courrier Francais (12 octobre 1835; 16 janvier 1836; 23 janvier 1836)
-2 issues of the Journal des Debats (17 decembre 1835; 6 janvier 1836)
-2 issues of La Paix (4 septembre 1836; 8 septembre 1836).
Boxes 11-12
Notes and drafts for 1862 edition of L'Irlande.
Also:

-4 letters of Florent Richomme to Gustave de Beaumont: 18 septembre 1859; 26 septembre 1859; 3 avril 1860; 1 with no date.
-Criticism of L'Irlande by _________.
-1 issue of La Chronique de l'Ouest (28 mai 1862).
-Printed letter of Desplanches to Mgr Dupanloup, eveque d'Orleans.

did.unittitle: Tocqueville & Beaumont 1832-1840: Miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: a. Newspaper reviews of De la Democratie en Amerique.
b. Manuscripts and notes.

1. Tocqueville notes of Conversation avec Sharpe, 8 June 1835, on "Organisation politique: Parois[ses?] et Comtes." (Copy. Original sent to rejoin English travel notes in Tocqueville Tocqueville archives, 1964.)
2. Gustave de Beaumont: Note on visit to catacombs with Mayor Richards, 21 7bre, 1834.
3. Gustave de Beaumont: "Philosophie de l'histoire: Lois generales accidents."
4. Gustave de Beaumont: Notes on Rivarol.
5. Gustave de Beaumont: Notes on Sully.
6. Gustave de Beaumont: "L'Influence des Moeurs sur les Lois"
7. Gustave de Beaumont: "L'Homme ne pour la Societe"'
8. Gustave de Beaumont: "Philosophie. De ce qui est vrai ou faux"
9. Gustave de Beaumont: Latin quotes from Ulpian?
10. Notes on Thiers's French Revolution (by both Tocqueville and Beaumont)
11. Gustave de Beaumont Notes on Greece, 2 small folders.
12. Tocqueville: "Visite a Kenilworth," 3 pages. (Original, from Larminat)
13. 2 pages on English workingmen and "caisses d'epargne" (Tocqueville original, from Larminat)
14. Pamphlet, Rev. H. Price, Reasons in Support of an Extention of the Elective Franchise..., 1836. (For this see Hume Letters, C.I.e.)

did.unittitle: b. Tocqueville Notes, Speeches, Writings, Pamphlets - 1840-1859.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1. Axiomes d'economie politique. 1 p. (Larminat)
2. Voltaire a dit..." 3 pages (Larminat)
3. Tocqueville as Foreign minister. Document addressed to the King of Sardinia, signed by L. N. Bonaparte and A. de Tocqueville, Paris, 6 Oct. 1849.
4. Printed documents.
-21 avril 1842, Discours de M. de Tocqueville at the Academie francaise on M. de Cessac.
-2 Dec. 1851, Derniere seance de l'Assemblee Nationale
-3 avril 1852, Discours de M. de Tocqueville, Academie des sciences morales et politiques.
-14 juillet 1866, Lettre sur les derniers moments d'Alexis de Tocqueville Comte Ed. de Tocqueville a Mignet.
-"Faire-part" of Tocqueville's death, 16 avril 1859.
5. Printed document: "A Messieurs les electeurs du Canton de Montebourg." Tocqueville's letter of retirement to his constituency. 29 avril 1852.
6. Tocqueville Estate and Household Accounts (1856-1859):
-Contract [?] de la valeur de toutes les terres de Tocqueville suivant les cadastres (1856).
-Short list of farm tenures.
-Scrap on coal and cider.
-Reglement fait avec Birette, 1 9bre 1857.
-Conventions avec Birette.
-Cidre: consommation dans la maison.
-Salaire de Birette, 8 8bre 1857.
-Parcelles de terre cedees par le fermier, et contenance du parc et jardin.
(These were received from Mme de Larminat and after Xerox copies were made for Yale, the originals were sent to Andre Jardin for the Tocqueville archives.)

E.IV.e. CATALOGUES AND INVENTORIES OF TOCQUEVILLE MANUSCRIPT COLLECTIONS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Altogether we know of seven catalogues or inventories of Tocqueville manuscripts. Originally Paul L. White made three [1W] [2W] [3W]. Then GWP inventoried what in 1930 he found at Tocqueville [T], and what by 1938 had been collected at Yale [Y]. In the late 1930's someone reclassified the manuscripts at Tocqueville [XT]. Finally in 1955-56 Andre Jardin made his own inventory of what had been turned over by Comte Jean de Tocqueville to the editors of the new "definitive" edition at the Bibliotheque de l'Institut.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.1. [1W] (First?)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Catalogue made by Paul Lambert White in 1919 or 1920 (with typed copy by GWP in 1959). No title. In 21 manuscript pages. Lists 19 bundles or packages of Tocqueville's American Manuscripts, which I believe White found at the Tocqueville Chateau in Normandy (see description of package 15 by White). GWP saw most of the originals there in 1929-31. Copies, made for White and for GWP by Bonnel, are now at Yale. See [Y] below. But some of the originals have been mislaid or have disappeared.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.2. [2W] (Second?)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Catalogue made by White in 1919 or 1920 (with typed copy by GWP in 1938). No title. In 62 pages. Lists 7 great packages, each package containing many dossiers. This appears to be the inventory of all the Tocqueville and related manuscripts which White found with Antoine Redier, who was working on a biography of Tocqueville. A huge collection. Out of it White apparently took certain American materials (see [3W] below) for reproduction by Abel Doysie's copyists. The rest were apparently never copied for White or for Yale. A certain number got back to the Tocqueville Chateau, and are now available (see Jardin's notes for GWP typed copy), but the greater part have simply disappeared.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.3. [3W] (Third?)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Catalogue made by White, in 1919 or 1920 (with typed copy by GWP in 1959). No title. In 20 pages. Lists 5 dossiers (changed from an original 3). Analyzes the American materials, apparently found with Redier (see [2W] above) and set aside for copying by Doysie's copyists. Scrap of paper gives the instructions for copying. Many of the copies are now at Yale, but some important files never got to Yale. Very few of the originals seem ever to have got back to Tocqueville, and almost all of them were missing in 1956-57.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.4. [T] Inventaire des documents d'Alexis de Tocqueville by GWP.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tocqueville Tocqueville MSS: brief classification of the Tocqueville manuscript archive at the Tocqueville Chateau, as found and reorganized by GWP in 1930. The ribbon copy of this Inventaire was given to Comte Jean de Tocqueville; a carbon copy is at Yale. All the manuscripts here listed ought still to be in existence, though the Jardin Inventory [J] shows that certain manuscripts have either been set aside or mislaid or lost, while some additional manuscripts have been found. The Yale copy of [T] is annotated to show the differences noted between [T] and [J] by Jardin in 1956.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.5. [XT]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inventory or new classification made at Tocqueville by M. [?] in 193[?]. GWP has never seen a copy. Presumably in hands of Comte de Tocqueville.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.6. [J]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inventaire made by M. Andre Jardin in the years 1955?-56 of all the Tocqueville manuscripts, as confided to the care of the Commission Nationale pour la publication des Oeuvres d'Alexis de Tocqueville, and deposited in the Bibliotheque de l'Institut. This inventory shows that certain manuscripts have been withheld, or mislaid or lost, since [T] was made. Also many manuscripts from [2W] apparently never got back into the Tocqueville archives. Use restricted.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.7. [Y] Catalogue of Tocqueville-Beaumont Archive at Yale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Originally constructed by GWP in 1938, in two copies of 41 pages. In 1959 revised and enlarged to include important acquisitions of recent years. In 1964 again enlarged and retyped. Shows what original manuscripts, what copies, and whate notes had been accumulated at the Yale Library or in the personal possession of GWP. Identifies the source of each document or photo or copy.

did.unittitle: E.IV.e.8. [8] The lost Tocqueville manuscripts (all in our GWP files)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: a. List of lost Tocqueville American manuscripts
b. List of lost Tocqueville manuscripts of all kinds.
c. Correspondence on lost Tocqueville and Beaumont manuscripts
d. Some possibilities (1959)

Note: A number of the copies of Tocqueville and Beaumont manuscripts, made by Doysie about 1920-1921, or by Bonnel later, now have a superior value, since the originals have apparently disappeared (see repeated comments above).

In the summer of 1959, GWP had White's catalogues 1W and 3W copied by typewriter in such a form as to make it easier to identify each document and to find its present location or the location of some copy. In the year 1955-56, GWP consulted Andre Jardin who was secretary for the committee publishing the new definitive edition of the Works of Alexis de Tocqueville. Jardin compared his own inventory [J], with catalogues [T], [1W], [2W], and [3W], and made some notes to indicate what he thought was missing from his own collections. These will be found in the appropriate folders, E.IV.e. 1, 2, 3, 4.

E.IV.e.4. then becomes key: Inventaire des Documents d'Alexis de Tocqueville, with notes by GWP and Andre Jardin to indicate what was missing in Paris in 1956, and what may either have been lost or withheld by Comte de Tocqueville from the archives at the Bibliotheque de l'Institut.

did.unittitle: G. W. Pierson - Further information for the use of the Tocqueville MSS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Before anyone does extensive work with these papers, he or she should be familiar with certain facts in their history.

did.unittitle: E.V.a. The Beaumont Connections:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: When Alexis de Tocqueville died in 1859, he left all his papers with his wife, Mary Mottley. This Englishwoman, who was not popular with Tocqueville's brothers and their families, first authorized Gustave de Beaumont to publish many of Tocqueville's papers in the Oeuvres Completes, which Beaumont proceeded to edit. Then, on her death in 1865, she left all of Tocqueville's manuscripts to Gustave de Beaumont: i.e. outside the family.

The Tocquevilles were outraged at such a breach of family usage, and no better pleased to have the publication and royalty rights (including the title to the as yet unpublished "Souvenirs") falling to Beaumont's son, Antonin. In 1891, therefore, in consideration of a certain sum of money, Comte Christian de Tocqueville secured title and possession again for his family. Unfortunately, the heirs of the two principals to this bargain were long inclined to believe that perfect faith had not or might not have been kept - the Tocquevilles suspecting that not all of the papers were delivered, the Beaumonts nursing a vague feeling that they might have been done out of something.

To settle the thing in my own mind, I went over the Beaumont-la-Chartre and the Tocqueville Chateau papers very carefully, compared my findings with the bill of sale, and was soon thoroughly persuaded that good faith had been kept. The bill of sale seemed to cover substantially all of the Tocqueville papers that the Beaumonts had possessed, except Tocqueville's letters to Beaumont which belonged to the Beaumont family, and except for Tocqueville's notes on their prison book on which Beaumont had done most of the work. I told both of the families that things seemed to have been handled with honor and they professed to believe me; however, such legends die hard. In any case, to work with the papers of two mutually suspicious families was, and perhaps will remain, a delicate matter.

did.unittitle: E.V.b. Certain of the Tocqueville and certain of the Beaumont papers have disappeared.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (See above, E.IV.e.)

When White visited France in 1920-1921, he found the Tocqueville manuscripts above referred to partly in the Tocqueville Chateau and partly in the Paris office of Antoine Redier, who was then engaged in writing his Comme disait Monsieur de Tocqueville... (1926). These last papers have never been fully returned to the Tocqueville Chateau, though Redier told me in 1931 that he no longer had them but had returned them to the Tocqueville family. One possible explanation is that Redier managed to mislay some of them. I saw him and got the impression that he had too many irons in the fire and had a terrible memory. I talked with him several times and, the last time in 1931, he still had some Beaumont family papers which I returned to the Beaumonts for him, with apologies for his oversight. Another clue may be that Redier loaned some Tocqueville manuscripts to Roland-Marcel, who was doing a thesis on Tocqueville, and Roland-Marcel may not have returned them. It is possible again that the young Tocquevilles after the death of Comte Christian, their father (it was he that made the arrangements with Redier and with White), may have mislaid the papers returned by Redier. In this case, the lost manuscript should be at 4 rue de Chanaleilles, Paris 7e, which I have never had the chance to search. In any case, I am certain that some of the Redier Tocqueville manuscripts were not at Tocqueville in 1929-1931, and had dropped out of sight since 1921; while still others which I saw at Tocqueville have not been turned over to the editors at the Institut.

did.unittitle: E.V.c.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A scholar working in the Yale Tocqueville MSS. should realize that by far the greatest archive is that now in the hands of the committee which is editing the so-called Definitive Edition of the works of Alexis de Tocqueville, under a national commission, supported by the French government and indirectly drawing on some support from the Rockefeller Foundation. The editors have accumulated the Tocqueville papers at the library of the Institut and have been publishing under the directorship of J. Peter Mayer and an editorial committee headed by Charles Pouthas, with Andre Jardin as Secretaire. J. Peter Mayer got microfilms or transcripts of certain of the missing documents from copies of same in the Yale Tocqueville Manuscripts. He has then published the Tocqueville American Diaries in French and presently in an English edition. The Yale documents, therefore, should always be checked against the published volumes. The same is true, or will be true, of the Tocqueville - Beaumont Correspondence which Charles Pouthas and others have been editing.
Unfortunately, during the process of getting out this edition, the papers have not been available to scholars.

Ultimately, it would be well if a copy of the Yale Catalogue [Y] could be made available to the Tocqueville Archives in Paris and a copy of the Jardin Inventaire [J] could be available in the Yale MSS. (This has now been done on a personal basis - 1964)

did.unittitle: Comments of Tocqueville scholars on Yale Tocqueville MSS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Andre Jardin comments on Yale Catalogue and manuscript collection as of 1963: page numbers refer to old catalogue.

"Les Archives de Yale, beaucoup moins considerables que les archives privees familiales de Tocqueville, sont cependant en importance le second centre de renseignement sur cet auteur. Si elles sont muettes sur des annees entieres de la vie de celui-ci, elles sont irremplacables pour les annees qui ont precede la publication de la Democratie . Tout essai sur la genese de la pensee de Tocqueville devrait partir de cette source. Ajoutons qu'avec la documentation imprimee et les archives du Quai d'Orsay, elles suffiraient a un "scholar" qui voudrait ecrire une vie de Beaumont.
En suivant l'ordre de l'inventaire, je vais donner quelques precisions et noter ce qui m'a paru errone. Je suis a la disposition de M. Pierson pour toutes explications supplementaires.
A.I. (page 4)
L'intervention du Comte Herve pour la mise a la retraite du vieux Juge Lafontaine est interessante, parce qu'a ce moment l'ancien prefet s'efforce de faire avancer dans le tribunal son fils Alexis.
A.III. (page 5)

Le partage des lettres de Tocqueville a Beaumont entre les archives de Tocqueville et Yale parait le fruit du hasard. Une lettre de 1837 est meme partagee entre les deux fonds. Cependant la tres grande majorite des lettres anterieures a 1843 se trouve a Yale; au contraire la plupart des lettres posterieures a cette date sont a Tocqueville.

Cette premiere serie de lettres appelle, a mon avis, les observations suivantes: Madame de Larminat pour des raisons obscures a retire de cette correspondance un texte amusant de Tocqueville sur Beaumont "Deux mots sur vous". La lettre cataloguee "10 mars 1829" me parait en realite du 9 mars.
La lettre cataloguee "15 mars 1829" me parait en realite du 18 mars.
A.IV. (page 6)
Quelques dates me paraissent inexactes:

-Ligne 2: 6 juillet 1816 (cachet 1817)
-Ligne 3: 20 juillet 1817: plutot 28 juillet 1817
-Ligne 23: 27 mai 1817: plutot 27 mars 1817
A.VII. (p.8)

Les lettres signalees comme de Louis de Kergorlay a Tocqueville du
-25 septembre 1830
-25 octobre 1830 sont en realite des lettres d'Henrion a Tocqueville.

De meme, les lettres de Tocqueville du
-17 octobre 1830
-19 novembre 1830 sont adressees a Henrion.
Henrion, camarade de Tocqueville a Metz et avec qui il semble avoir eu des rapports orageux; futur magistrat et auteur d'une histoire ecclesiastique.
Par ailleurs la lettre a Charles Stoffels (ligne 3) est bien d'aout et non d'avril.
B.I.a.2. Copies des lettres d'Amerique d'A. de Tocqueville
Ces copies, faites pour la plupart par Redier, correspondent-elles a des originaux egares? Dans l'etat actuel de mon information, voici ce que je pense:
-les manuscrits des lettres a ses parents et a ses freres n'ont pas et‚ retrouves.
-Par contre des lettres a des cousins (Mme de Leusse) ou des amis (Ernest de Chabrol) existent chez leurs heritiers ou les acquereurs de ces bibliotheques.
B.I.b.2. Lettres de Beaumont d'Amerique.
Le cahier de copies de ces lettres est de la main de Gustave de Beaumont. Dans le cas unique ou l'original a survecu, la copie est absolument fidele.

Ces lettres me paraissent assez interessantes pour etre publiees; elles sont spontanees, vives, ingenieuses. L'edition serait facile a faire, la plupart des eclaircissements se trouvant dans la these de G.W. Pierson. J'ai parle a M. Renouvin (et a lui seul) d'une possibilite de les editer et il serait dispose, je crois a demander une aide du C.N.R.S. pour ce leger volume. Je crois qu'une edition americaine en anglais pourrait aussi etre prevue car j'ai constate que bien des recits de voyageurs du XIXeme sieecle se vendent en editions courantes.

Reste la question de la publication des croquis de Beaumont. Il me semble que certains sont en double et qu'il faudrait se borner a ceux tres vraisemblablement pris sur place. Cela pose une question du nombre des croquis a publier et des frais d'impression.
M. Pierson peut seul prendre une decision. Je suis a sa disposition pour des demarches ou une collaboration a ce travail.
B.I.c.

Page 20 ligne 8 - La lettre de Tocqueville a Sparks porte deux dates: 18 octobre et 18 decembre 1832. La seconde me parait la bonne, la premiere pouvant etre une transcription fautive de Xbre en Octobre.
Page 21 ligne 3. Cette lettre du 25 juillet 1831 est peut-etre d'Elie de Beaumont.
Elie de Beaumont (frere d'un celebre geologue) etait magistrat a Versailles. Cousin de Gustave, il devait epouser plus tard une fille de Le Peletier d'Aunay, cousin de Tocqueville.
(Mais je n'ai pas encore elucide le point de savoir si d'Aunay n'etait pas aussi cousin de Gustave et Elie de Beaumont egalement cousin d'Alexis.)

Page 21 ligne 4: lettre du 16 aout de Le Peletier d'Aunay.
-ligne 5: lettre d'Aunay probablement a Beaumont et non a Tocqueville.
-ligne 7: la lettre d'Avallon semble emaner de Raudot, ancien collegue de Tocqueville a Versailles, futur depute de 1840.
-lignes 8 et 9: Mareil et non Navail.
B.I.f. p. 24

Le projet de lettre de Philadelphie (1) du 10 novembre plutot que du 10 octobre. D'apres G.W. Pierson, les deux amis ne sont pas encore a cette date a Philadelphie, ils y achevent un second sejour le 10 novembre.
Le 13: brouillon de lettre Tocqueville a d'Aunay.
B.IV., B.V.
Le dossier B.IV. est transfere en C.I., B.V. devrait donc devenir B.IV.

Copie des lettres de Beaumont a Tocqueville par Bonnel sur des cahiers. Une partie des lettres des deux premiers cahiers n'existent plus en totalite ou en partie. Leur recherche parait bien difficile: Bonnel est mort, sa seule heritiere est une religieuse...
p. 35, ligne 1: la lettre du 9 juillet est partagee entre Tocqueville et Yale.
C.I.c.
page 37, alinea 2, ligne 4. Lettre "Je suis aussi profondement". Lettre destinee a Louis de Kergorlay plutot qu'a Stoffels.
C.I.d.
p. 40, ligne 12, lettre de Charles Sumner du 1er mai 1857 plutot que du 1er mai 1837.
C.VIII.
Les "additions, observations, supplementary notes of German translator" traduites en francais (page 44) de la main de Louis de Kergorlay.
C.IX.b.1.

Conversation avec Sharpe. C'est en realite un fragment du voyage d'Angleterre que Mayer et Jardin n'ont pu publier puisqu'ils l'ignoraient. Tout le reste du manuscrit du voyage est aux archives Tocqueville.
C.IX.c.

La lettre du 21 mai 1834 (page 48 avant-derniere ligne) est d'Hippolyte de Tocqueville. Il y encourage Hyde de Neuville a se presenter aux elections contre son propre beau-frere Bricqueville (qui facilitera les debuts politiques d'Alexis).
Derniere ligne: Bonnardel et non Bonnordet.
D.I.c.
page 50, ligne 3: "1840" peut etre precisee "28 juillet 1840"
page 50, 3 lignes avant la fin: "23 mai" au lieu de "26 mai" (error: we have both.)
page 51, ligne 13: "3 novembre 1853" au lieu de "3 octobre"
30 octobre 1854: la date de la lettre etant donne son contenu, est erronee. Probablement 1853. (no letter of such date!)
D.II.a.
page 53, ligne 1: Je ne crois pas la date de 1830 possible. Je propose 26 ou 27 juillet 1844.
page 54, ligne 14: Je crois avoir retrouve une reponse a cette lettre de W.W. a la Columbia University Library.
D.III.a.
page 60, lignes 1 et 2: le destinataire de ces deux lettres semble etre Mignet.
page 60, ligne 3: lettre de l'Architecte Harou-Romain (et non Barou Romain)
So far as possible the above suggestions and corrections have been incorporated in this current 1964-66 catalogue Y. (January 1967)
Comments by an unidentified scholar

I think that C.XI.b. 13 may not derive from the English journey because of the passage... "J'indique ces divers etablissement a Gustave comme... " Would he be inclined to write this if Beaumont were at his side? Perhaps this is written shortly before the journey, or even years after, when Tocqueville became quite interested in savings banks and Beaumont did a study of working class problems and savings banks (my guess). However, the paper on which this is written could perhaps be checked against those of the 1835 journey to see if this throws any light on the dating. I just checked against a letter by Tocqueville to Beaumont (C.I.a.2: 14 mai 1837) and it fits C.XI.b. 13 perfectly, even asking Gustave for special information in the banks of Scotland. I think it can be safely dated shortly before May 14, 1837 - i.e. during Beaumont's solo visit to England.
C.XI. b. 12
See the date faintly in pencil at upper left of first page - 26 aout 1833, isn't it? - This is obviously a letter to family or fiancee since line 9 reads "imagine toi"?
C.I.b.
Is dating of 1st letter 20 July 1831 wrong? Wasn't Tocqueville in America in July 1831?
C.XI.b. 3

Philosophie de l'histoire - most of these belong with L'Irlande or are at least connected with it. I am considering going through L'Irlande again this winter - would you like me to attempt a rearrangement if I do?
D.IV.l.
24 fevrier 1848 instead of 1858?

Just checked against a letter by T. to B (C.I.a.2: 14 mai 1837) and it fits the C.XI.b. 13 perfectly, even asking Gustave for special information in the banks of Scotland. I think it can be safely dated shortly before May 14, 1837 - i.e. during Beaumont's solo visit to England.
This note has been filed in box marked 'Discarded Catalogues and Notes'; perhaps someone can identify the handwriting.
14 November 1966
